docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama says he is eager for substantive negotiations Thursday when he convenes Democrats and Republicans at Blair House for a bipartisan meeting on health care. But before the negotiations, there are the negotiations -- talks about who sits where, who gets to talk, and what the agenda will be. The White House has a broad sketch for the six-hour session, based on consultations with House and Senate leaders in both parties. An official, speaking on condition of anonymity, discussed the administration's vision for how the meeting will play out.
docs.abstract: Negotiations are underway to decide who sits where, who gets to talk and what will be on agenda when Pres Obama convenes Democrats and Republicans for bipartisan meeting on health care (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Ever since his days as a community organizer, President Obama has believed that by listening and appealing to reason, he can bring people together to get results. But will his gentle, consensus-building style be enough to pass health legislation?

headline.sub: Does a Gentle, Consensus-Building Style Work?

docs.snippet: Ever since his days as a community organizer, President Obama has believed that by listening and appealing to reason, he can bring people together to get results. But will his gentle, consensus-building style be enough to pass health legislation?

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama says he is eager for substantive negotiations when he convenes Democrats and Republicans for a bipartisan health summit at Blair House on Thursday. But before those negotiations, there are other negotiations - talks about who sits where, who gets to talk and precisely what the agenda will be.
